Note by the President of the Board off Trade.This Bill seeks to give effect to an agreed^code of rules . The extent to which shipowners should be allowed to limit their liability for loss or damage to goods by the insertion of clauses in Bills of Lading has been a matter of dispute between shipowners and shippers over a long period. The attached draft Bill seeks to put into effect a Code of Rules on which substantial agreement between shippers and shipowners has been reached.Ob3oot of Rules. Since about 1880 the practice has, grown of inserting in Bills of Lading clauses which exempt shipowners from certain common law liabilities for the safe carriage of goods. Shippers have represented that some of these clauses are unreasonable. The intention of the Rules is to set out the liabilities which shipowners ought reasonably to undertake *His Ma3'esty's Government are committed to legislation. In February 1921 the Imperial Shipping Committee recommended the adoption of uniform legislation throughout tho Empire on this subject and indicated the lines on which in their opinion such legislation should be framed. The recommendations were adopted at the Conference of Imperial Premiers in July, 1921.CABINET.-1- Rules recommended as basis, of International Convent.!on. Before effect could be given to these recommendations a set of Rules was adopted at the Hague at a Conference of shipowners, shippers, bankers, underwriters and other interests. These Rules, known, as the "Hague Rules", were not entirely in conformity with the recommendations of the Imperial Shipping Committee, but they were subsequently amended by agreement between the interested parties to conform substantially to the recommendations of the Committee. These Rules, with certain alterations, were recommended by the delegates at the Brussels International Maritime Conference of October last, at which H.M. Government was represented, for adoption as the basis of a convention. This basis forms the schedule to the aotached Bill. A Report by the British Delegates of the proceedings at the Conference at Brussels in October last has recently been published by the Stationery Office.Provisions of Rules. Articles 1 and 2 are pre-liminary Articles. articles 3 and 4 define the liabilities out of which a shipowner may not contract and those from which he is exempt. Under Article 3 he must exercise due diligence to provide a seaworthy ship. Article 4 also provides for a maximum liability per package. These articles carry out the recommendations of the Imperial Shipping Committee as to the precise definition cf the physical limits to the ship owners liability, and as to his maximum liability.Artiole 5 provides that a carrier may surrender his rights and immunities under Article 4. This allows a measure of freedom of contract. , - - 789article 6 allows the shipowner to make a special con-tract when goods are being carried under exceptional circum-stances. This is in accordance with a recommendation of the Imperial Shipping Committee.Provisions of draft Bill. The Bill itself is intended only to give legal sanction to the Rules.Clause I limits its application to outward shipments -This is to avoid conflict of laws. it may be observed that United States legislation and certain Colonial Acts apply to both outward and inward shipments.Clause II is necessary to repeal the implied absolute undertaking In British Common Lam to provide a seaworthy ship, as under the Rules the shipowner is only required to exercise due diligence to provide a seaworthy ship.Clause III- It is necessary that Bills of Lading shall contain an express statement that their effect is subject to the provisions of the Rules in order that these Rules shall apply when cases are heard before foreign courtsMuch controversy has arisen over this question of the liability of shipowners. It is mainly a matter for ship-owners and shippers to settle between themselves, and as they have arrived at substantial agreement it is desirable that legal effect should be given to the agreement to avoid further dispute. As stated by the Imperial Shipping Committee uniform legislation throughout the Empire is desirable, but it is still more desirable to have inter-national agreement. The Rules scheduled to the Bill have been recommended by the Brussels International Maritime Conference for adoption as the basis of an International Convention, and as they carry out substantially the recommendations of the Imperial Shipping Committee they meet the commitments of H.M.
